title-group.article-title: Integration of a discrete multi-component fuel evaporation model with a G-equation flame propagation combustion model and its validation

article-meta.aff: 1Engine Research Center, University of Wisconsin–Madison, USA
2Research and Advanced Engineering, Ford Motor Company, USA

author-notes.corresp: S Yang, Research and Advanced Engineering, Ford Motor Company 2101, Village Road, Dearborn, Michigan 48124, USA. Email: syang33@ford.com

abstract.p: A discrete multi-component fuel evaporation model has been successfully integrated with a G-equation flame propagation combustion model. In the discrete multi-component fuel evaporation model, the individual components of the fuel during the evaporation process are tracked, and the characteristics of the fuel components are determined from fuel libraries. In the G-equation flame propagation combustion model, five improved sub-models developed previously by the authors are used. Two new methods that are necessary for the integration are proposed. To consider the change of local fuel vapor mixture composition, a ‘blending cetane number approach’ is proposed that formulates the relationship between the fuel vapor mixture cetane number and the mole fraction and cetane number of each component. With the mixture cetane number, the research octane number can be calculated locally, and with this research octane number, the flame speed can be calculated. In the combustion stage, a ‘group chemistry method’ is proposed in which one representative species can be selected to represent several fuel components that belong to the same chemical family. This treatment makes it possible to use a smaller size of multi-component fuel chemical kinetic mechanism. Each sub-model included in the integrated model was validated to see if the integration process was correct or not, and finally the integrated model was tested to model complicated gasoline direct injection engine cases. Simulations of single-droplet and spray evaporation with discrete multi-component fuel cases from normal evaporation to flash boiling were performed and compared with available experimental data. The match between simulations and experiments is excellent. The G-equation flame propagation combustion model was also validated with experimental data. Evaporation and the combustion process were simulated for a gasoline direct injection engine. The simulated in-cylinder pressures are in good agreement with the experimental data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A real fuel generally contains hundreds or thousands of components, and it is important to represent the fuel components in the evaporation and combustion processes. Current treatments use a single component in the evaporation stage and use a corresponding single-component chemistry mechanism in the combustion stage. This method is used in most computational fluid dynamic codes, such as the KIVA code.1 The advantages of this method include that it is very simple and can save computer time. However, it cannot capture the complex behavior of the evaporation and combustion of multi-component fuels such as gasoline. The preferential evaporation of light-end components in multi-component fuels greatly affects the fuel distribution near the spray and cannot be represented by single-component models.2 A more advanced treatment, which is more appropriate for mixtures with large numbers of components, is to describe the mixture properties using the methods of continuous thermodynamics,3 in which the composition is represented by a continuous probability density function with respect to an appropriate parameter, such as molecular weight. This approach is called the continuous multi-component (CMC) model in this paper. This method enables a reduction of computational load without degrading the predictability of the complex behavior of the evaporation of multi-component fuels.2 However, when the CMC model is applied to combustion simulations, especially with detailed chemistry, describing the multi-component features of the fuel is inevitably limited, making it difficult to model the consumption of individual components appropriately. Since the exact fuel species are not known in the CMC model, generally single-component chemistry is used in the combustion stage.

While many fuels can be composed of hundreds of hydrocarbons, many fuels can also be accurately modeled with a smaller number of fuel components (≤10).4 For this reason, some researchers5–7 choose to use a discrete multi-component (DMC) fuel model. The DMC approach tracks the individual components of the fuel during the evaporation process and allows coupling with the reaction kinetics of the individual fuel components. In the DMC model, the fuel is modeled as discrete fuel species, the characteristics of which are determined from fuel libraries. The DMC model is a better representation of real fuels for both evaporation and combustion, and this method is also computationally affordable.

However, in the work of Torres et al.,5 Tonini et al.6 and Ra and Reitz,7 only multi-component fuel evaporation was considered. Multi-species fuel combustion was not considered. For engine simulations, combustion and pollutant emission formation are of special concern. Due to their importance, the effects of multi-component fuels on the combustion process, flame propagation and laminar flame speed, and the effect of different fuel components on chemistry, must also be considered.

The level-set method (G-equation) is a powerful tool to model both premixed and partially premixed combustion occurring in spark ignition (SI) engines. With its application to combustion, Williams8 first suggested use of a transport equation for a non-reactive scalar, G, for laminar flame propagation. Peters9,10 subsequently extended this approach to the turbulent flame regime. The turbulent G-equation concept has been successfully applied to SI engine combustion simulations by Dekena and Peters,11 Tan12 and Ewald and Peters.13 A large amount of work has been carried out on developing detailed chemical kinetic mechanisms for fuel oxidation and pollutant formation.14 Liang et al.15–17 successfully incorporated detailed chemical kinetics into a G-equation-based turbulent combustion model. Specifically, for SI engine combustion, detailed fuel oxidation mechanisms coupled with a reduced nitrogen oxide (NOX) mechanism are applied behind the mean flame front for modeling post flame combustion and NOX formation. The chemical kinetic mechanisms are also applied ahead of the flame front for predicting compression auto-ignition of the end gas (knock). Also in Liang’s work, in the course of coupling detailed chemistry with the G-equation combustion model for the primary heat release calculation within the flame front, laminar and turbulent flame speed correlations were improved for a better description of the turbulent flame propagation process.

In the G-equation-based turbulent combustion model, the laminar flame speed is very important for determining the propagation of the flame front (G = 0) surface. In addition, the local and instantaneous residual value has a great effect on the evaluation of the laminar flame speed. For the calculation of the residual value, Yang et al.18 explored several different empirical methods. In Yang’s work, several improvements to the G-equation combustion sub-models were proposed, including the precise calculation of ‘primary heat release’ based on the sub-grid scale unburned/burnt volumes of flame-containing cells, and modeling flame-front quenching in highly stratified mixtures. Yang et al.19 proposed a transport equation residual model incorporating a Damkohler criterion for accurately calculating the local and instantaneous residual in each cell and fundamentally describing the combustion process in the flame-containing cells.
However, in the work of Tan,12 Liang et al.15,16 and Yang et al.,18,19 the fuel was assumed to be a single-component fuel.

As mentioned above, previous researchers have developed multi-component fuel evaporation models, such as the DMC model, but in their work, multi-component fuel combustion was not considered. In addition, previous researchers have developed flame propagation combustion models, such as the G-equation model, but in the evaporation stage, only single-component evaporation modeling was used. The new points introduced in the present work include integrating the DMC fuel evaporation model with the G-equation flame propagation combustion model, testing each sub-model included in the integrated code from single-droplet evaporation cases to cylindrical chamber spray evaporation cases for validating the integration correct or not, and verifying that the integrated model is a successful, stable and practical code for modeling complicated gasoline direct injection (GDI) engines. Two new methods that are necessary for the integration are proposed. To consider the change of local fuel vapor mixture composition, a ‘blending cetane number approach’ is proposed that formulates the relationship between the fuel vapor mixture cetane number and the mole fraction and cetane number of each component. With the mixture cetane number, the research octane number (RON) can be calculated. In the combustion stage, a ‘group chemistry method’ is proposed in which one representative species can be selected to represent several fuel components that belong to the same chemical family. This treatment makes it possible to use a reasonably sized multi-component fuel chemical kinetic mechanism. To validate the DMC fuel evaporation model, simulations of the evaporation of a single droplet with a single-component fuel, a single droplet with a multi-component fuel under various temperature and pressure conditions, and simulations of the evaporation of a spray with a single-component fuel and a spray with a multi-component fuel, were performed. Finally, several gasoline turbocharged direct injection (GTDI) engine combustion cases were simulated and compared with experimental data.

sec.title: DMC fuel evaporation model
sec.p: A spherical liquid droplet with a finite number of components vaporizing without chemical reactions in a gaseous environment is considered. Radiation and second-order effects, such as the Soret and Dufour effects, are assumed to be negligible. With the fuel components treated as discrete species and assuming no absorption of the ambient gas into the liquid droplet, the system is a discrete system consisting of the liquid-phase fuel species and a discrete mixture system of vapor phase fuel and ambient gas.

sec.title: Calculation of average properties of liquid and vapor phase fuel
sec.p: Assuming the liquid fuel to be an ideal mixture of multi-components, average thermal and transport properties of the liquid phase can be defined. In addition, the properties of fuel vapor–air mixtures are calculated based on the gas-phase properties of the individual fuel components. The fuel properties considered in the present study include the density of the liquid fuel, vapor pressure, surface tension, liquid viscosity and thermal conductivity, heat of evaporation, liquid heat capacity, fuel vapor diffusivity, thermal conductivity and viscosity. Detailed information about the correlations and formulations of the properties can be found in Ra and Reitz.7

sec.title: G-equation flame propagation and chemical kinetic model
Improved G-equation combustion sub-models
sec.p: In our previous work,18–20 five improved combustion sub-models were developed for modeling gasoline engines with a level-set G-equation and detailed chemical kinetics. These combustion sub-models included a transport equation residual model, introduction of a Damkohler criterion model for assessing the combustion regime of flame-containing cells, precise calculation of ‘primary heat release’ based on the sub-grid scale unburned/burnt volumes of flame-containing cells, modeling flame-front quenching in highly stratified mixtures, and the use of a recently developed primary reference fuel (PRF) mechanism in which the tetradecane (c14h30) reactions are included. To consider the tetradecane, 10 more species (c14h30, c14h29, c14h29o2, c14ket12, c12h25co, c5h10, c4h7, c4h7o, ch3cho and ch3co) and 30 more reactions were added to the PRF mechanism. In the transport equation residual model, a fictitious species concept is introduced to account for the residual gases in the cylinder, which have a great effect on the laminar flame speed. The residual gases include CO2, H2O and N2 remaining from the previous engine cycle or introduced using exhaust gas recirculation (EGR). This pseudo species is described by a transport equation. The transport equation residual model differentiates between CO2 and H2O from the previous engine cycle or EGR and that which is from the combustion products of the current engine cycle. The Damkohler criterion model is based on a comparison between a laminar flame propagation time scale and the chemical kinetic time scale to determine whether the level-set G-equation model or chemical kinetics should be used for assessing the combustion processes in flame-containing cells. The results from implementation of the Damkohler model range between the G-equation model and pure chemistry, depending on the conditions. The improved ‘primary heat release’ calculation model precisely considers the chemical kinetic heat release in unburned regions of flame-containing cells, and thus is thought to be physically reasonable. The simulation results show that the flame-front quenching model effectively captures the flame quench phenomenon in highly stratified mixtures that are typical in GDI engines. Validation of the new PRF mechanism shows that the calculated ignition delay matches shock tube data very well over a wide range of conditions. Detailed descriptions about these combustion sub-models can be seen in Yang et al.18–20

sec.title: Integration of the DMC model with the G-equation combustion model
sec.p:
The task of this section is to integrate the DMC evaporation model with the G-equation combustion model. In the liquid phase, the component index is from 1, 2, ……, to msp (total component number). In the gas phase, the species index is determined by the chemistry mechanism. This requires a mapping rule from the liquid phase to the gas phase. The mapping rule is

The detailed process of this treatment has been included in the integrated code. In the G-equation combustion model, at G = 0 (i.e. the flame front) region the chemical equilibrium (CEQ) solver is used, and in unburned and burned regions, the chemical kinetic model is used. However, in the flame-front region, determining the multi-component fuel PRF number is important. This is the task of the following subsection. If the number of fuel components is large and corresponding chemical kinetic mechanisms are not available, a ‘group chemistry method’ is used, which will be discussed in the section on the group chemistry method for modeling chemical kinetics.

sec.title: Blending cetane number approach for integrating the DMC fuel model and the G-equation combustion model
sec.p: In the DMC fuel model described above, the fuel composition is represented by discrete components. The mean molecular weight of the fuel can be calculated from the fraction and the molecular weight of each component. However, this calculated mean molecular weight is not the real mean molecular weight of the fuel because only a finite number of components is considered to represent the real fuel. As a result, the PRF-adaptive approach proposed in Yang and Reitz20 for the CMC fuel model cannot be used any more. Indeed, the PRF number calculated from the correlation in Yang and Reitz20 based on the mean molecular weight from the DMC model will be incorrect. To correctly calculate the flame speed, a blending cetane number approach is introduced in this paper.

In most cases, it is possible to compute a blending cetane number. For example, data from Olson et al.22 show that the cetane number of a blend of 10% benzene with a base fuel of cetane number 38.3, is 36.8. sec.title: Group chemistry method for modeling chemical kinetics
sec.p: In the flame-front region, the CEQ solver is used. Therefore, the above flame speed correlation plus the blending cetane number approach are enough to calculate the combustion process in the flame-front primary heat release region. The species can be the same as the fuel components from the evaporation stage. For the end-gas region in front of the flame and for the high-temperature products region after the flame, the chemical kinetic mechanism is used for reaction calculation. To reduce the size of the chemical kinetic mechanism, a group chemistry method is proposed in this work. In this method, some components from the evaporation stage, which belong to the same chemical family, are grouped into a single species before calling the chemical kinetic solver. Redistribution of the grouped components is done after the chemistry calculation for each time step, based on the mass proportion of the components before the chemistry calculation; that is, assuming that the reactivity of the components grouped into the same chemistry surrogate class is the same. Suppose fuel components i = 1, 2, ……, N′ are in the iso-paraffin family (or other chemical families, such as n-paraffin, aromatic, olefin, naphthene). sec.title: Code development
sec.p: The DMC fuel evaporation model was integrated with the improved G-equation combustion and the detailed chemical kinetic model in the KIVA-3V release2 code. In the integration, the ‘blending cetane number approach’ and the ‘group chemistry method’ described above were used. The updated laminar flame speed correlation described above was also implemented into the code.

sec.title: Validation of the DMC fuel evaporation model in the integrated code
sec.p: The present DMC fuel evaporation model was first applied to study single stagnant droplet evaporation. Various fuel temperatures, ambient gas pressures and temperatures were considered in order to assess the performance of the model in both the normal and flash-boiling evaporation modes. Evaporation of typical gasoline fuel was modeled. In addition, the present model was applied to simulate the evaporation of single stagnant droplets of gasoline mixed with ethanol. Then, the DMC fuel evaporation model was applied to study spray evaporation in a cylindrical chamber.

sec.title: Comparison between simulation and available experimental data
sec.p: The DMC evaporation model in the integrated code was first compared with the experimental results of Gokalp et al.24 and Nomura et al.25 for single- and binary-component droplet evaporation. Figure 1 shows comparisons of the drop size change history of n-heptane droplets under stationary, micro-gravity conditions. The experimental data are from Nomura et al.25 The ambient pressure is 1.0 bar, and the initial drop diameter is 0.6 mm. It is seen that the model predictions are in good agreement with the experimental measurements for various ambient temperatures.

caption.p: Comparisons of n-heptane drop size change history.

sec.title: Multi-component gasoline drop evaporation
sec.p: Evaporation of a single gasoline drop was simulated using the integrated code. In order to model the composition of typical gasoline fuel, seven hydrocarbon species were considered, as listed in Table 1. The distillation curves of the modeled fuel are shown in Figure 2. The measurement data are from Smith and Bruno,26 and the calculation conditions for the droplet and ambient N2 in Figure 2 are as follows: D0 = 100.0 µm, Td0 = 313.0 K, P0 = 1.0 bar, T0 = 500.0 K. It is seen that the predicted distillation characteristics of the fuel are in good agreement with the measured data of Smith and Bruno.26

caption.p: Comparison of distillation curves of gasoline fuel between modeled and measured data.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the behavior under normal evaporation conditions of the multi-component gasoline droplet in terms of the temperature of the drop’s interior and surface, the saturation temperature, and the component mass fractions in the drop interior and at the surface.

caption.p: Normal evaporation of a single gasoline drop: (a) droplet temperature, (b) surface composition, (c) interior composition.

sec.p: Figure 3(a) shows an interesting characteristic of multi-component fuel evaporation: due to preferential evaporation of the more volatile light-end components, the composition of the droplet changes continuously, and thus gasoline droplets do not reach an equilibrium condition, as in the corresponding case of the single-component iso-octane droplet. From the beginning, the droplet is heated by the heat flux from the hot ambient gas. However, the droplet surface temperature adjusts in order for the energy and mass balance to be satisfied, and the droplet experiences heating and/or cooling processes, depending on the temperature configuration surrounding the vaporizing droplet. The difference between the drop surface and interior temperatures decreases as the drop size decreases with time, as expected. During the drop life time, the total mass fraction of fuel components at the drop surface is less than unity, which confirms that evaporation occurs in the normal evaporation regime, as shown in Figure 3(b). As is expected, the surface mass fraction of the light-end component (iCth12) is high during the early period of evaporation and then it rapidly decreases as the evaporation proceeds. At the last stage of evaporation, only the heavy-end component (C12h26) remains in the droplet, as can be seen from the drop interior fuel components shown in Figure 3(c).

Flash boiling can be promoted when fuel is heated within an injector nozzle before injection. An initial drop temperature of 390.0 K was used to investigate this case. The other conditions were the same as in Figure 3. The saturation temperature is calculated to be 337.35 K for an ambient pressure of 1.0 bar with the initial composition of the present gasoline model fuel. As shown in Figure 4(a), within a short period of time (∼3 ms), the drop surface area is rapidly reduced due to flash boiling. Subsequently, the evaporation mode changes quickly to the normal evaporation mode. In the increased initial drop temperature case, the drop interior temperatures reach higher values (∼430.0 K) than those in the reduced ambient pressure case (∼405.0 K).

caption.p: Evaporation of a single superheated gasoline drop (a) mass and surface area, (b) droplet temperature, (c) surface composition, (d) interior composition.

sec.title: Drop evaporation of gasoline mixed with ethanol
sec.p: Evaporation of a single drop of gasoline mixed with ethanol was simulated using the integrated code. In the simulation, seven hydrocarbon species plus ethanol were considered, as listed in Table 2.

caption.p: Composition of gasoline mixed with ethanol (E10).

sec.p: Figure 5 shows the behavior under normal evaporation conditions of the droplet in terms of the variation of drop mass, drop surface area, temperature of the drop’s interior and surface, saturation temperature and the component mass fractions in the drop interior and at the surface. The initial drop diameter was 100.0 µm, initial drop temperature was 313.0 K, and the ambient pressure and temperature were 1.0 bar and 500.0 K, respectively.

caption.p: Normal evaporation of a single gasoline plus ethanol drop: (a) droplet temperature, (b) surface composition, (c) interior composition.

sec.p: Figure 5(a) to (c) is similar to Figure 3(a) to (c). However, there are two differences between gasoline evaporation and gasoline plus ethanol evaporation. One difference is that the drop life time in Figure 5 is shorter than that in Figure 3. The reason is that ethanol is a light-end component, and thus has a higher preference of evaporation than some heavy-end components in gasoline. The second difference is that although ethanol is the light-end component, it is not expected that ethanol has a higher surface mass fraction than ic5h12, as shown in Figure 5(b). The reason is that ethanol has a higher latent heat of evaporation than that of ic5h12. From the results in Figure 5, it is seen that the addition of ethanol into gasoline is a favorable method for fast droplet evaporation. Similar conclusions have also been reached by Jiao et al.,27 who considered non-ideal evaporation effects due to the azeotrope behavior of ethanol with polar components of gasoline.

sec.title: Spray evaporation in a cylindrical chamber
sec.p: The DMC model was also applied to simulations of solid cone sprays injected into a cylindrical chamber. The evaporation of multi-component sprays and single-component iso-octane sprays was considered. In the multi-component sprays, four components were considered. The four components and mass fractions were: iC8H18, 0.0625; iC5H12, 0.0600; C10H22, 0.0200; C2H5OH, 0.8575. A solid cone injector was used with a single injector hole of diameter 0.0153 cm and a spray cone angle of 30°. The ambient conditions were 500.0 K and 0.3 bar. An initial droplet temperature of 340.0 K was used for simulating the evaporation of the spray droplets. Physical spray sub-models used in this work include the standard KIVA collision model and the KH-RT break-up model. Predictions of the spray droplet distribution, flow field, and fuel mass fraction at time 20.0 ms for both single- and multi-component sprays using the DMC fuel model are shown in Figure 6(a) and (b). The in-cylinder vapor amount histories of the single- and multi-component cases are shown in Figure 6(c).

caption.p: Evaporation of single component and multi-component spray droplets: (a) single-component, (b) multi-component and (c) in-cylinder vapor amount.

sec.p: Figure 6(a) and (b) compares the spray droplet distributions, flow field and fuel mass fractions at time 20.0 ms after the start of injection between the multi-component and single-component iso-octane sprays. Due to preferential vaporization of the lighter components in the multi-component case, the fuel vapor distribution becomes wider upstream of the spray plume. In the late stages of the evaporation, there are more heavy components in the multi-component case than in the single-component case, so the fuel vapor distribution in the single-component case becomes wider downstream of the spray plume. Because the multi-component case has a faster evaporation rate initially, the drop size decreases rapidly in the initial stage, and thus the droplets and the ambient gas have higher velocities. It is also seen that the multi-component case has a longer penetration length. The droplets in the spray tip region comprise relatively heavier components, thus it takes a longer time for the droplets to vaporize completely. The overall evaporation rate was predicted to be slightly faster in the single-component iso-octane spray case than in the multi-component case. This can also be seen from Figure 6(c). In the initial evaporation stage, the multi-component case has a higher in-cylinder vapor amount than the single-component case, and in the later stage, the multi-component case has less in-cylinder vapor.

sec.title: Validation of the G-equation flame propagation and chemical kinetic model
sec.p: In our previous work,20 the SENKIN code28 was used to compute the ignition delay times of the new PRF mechanism. The good match of ignition delay times between the calculations and shock tube data showed that the new PRF mechanism could be used for calculations over a wide range of conditions. To test the G-equation combustion model, computations were performed by Tan and Reitz29 in a premixed charge SI engine. Measured wall heat flux data were used to validate the G-equation combustion model, and it was concluded that the flame propagation speed was well predicted by the present G-equation combustion model. In general, the agreement between the predicted and measured data are satisfactory in terms of its phasing. The flame arrival time at which the predicted heat flux increases sharply is almost the same as the corresponding time of the measured data. This indicates that the flame propagation speed is well predicted by the present G-equation combustion model.

PRF 91 engine case
sec.p: The present integrated DMC fuel evaporation model with the improved G-equation combustion and detailed chemical kinetic model was used for simulating a GTDI engine. The computational mesh for the cylinder, intake port and exhaust port of the engine is shown in Figure 7. The detailed specifications of this engine are shown in Table 3.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows droplet distributions and velocity vectors at various crank angles on a plane that bisects the intake valves. In Figure 8, the intake valves are located to the right half of the plane, and the injection starts during the intake stroke so that the velocity vectors are directed from the intake valves to the exhaust valves, and the spray droplets are substantially redirected. Figure 8(a) and (b) are in the middle stage of the intake stroke, so the gas velocities are higher and there are a lot of spray droplets. Figure 8(c) is at bottom dead center (BDC), so the gas velocities are smaller. In Figure 8(d), the spray droplets have almost evaporated completely.

caption.p: Droplet distribution and velocity vectors on a plane that bisects the intake valves.

sec.p: Iso-surfaces and iso-contours of the equivalence ratio in the cylinder are shown in Figure 9(a) to (e) for various crank angles. Figure 9(f) shows the total injected fuel, in-cylinder liquid and in-cylinder vapor amount as a function of crank angle. In Figure 9(a), an asymmetric iso-surface of equivalence ratio (corresponding to the value of φ = 0.5) is seen to reach the cylinder wall on the exhaust side of the chamber. It is seen that, before the end of injection, a higher equivalence ratio region exists inside the spray cone that is wide and extends along the spray centerline. The early vaporized fuel, which mostly consists of lighter components, diffuses quickly so that the maximum local equivalence ratio decreases and the distance between two adjacent iso-contours increases rapidly, as seen in Figure 9(b) to (e). In Figure 9(b) and (c), the value of the right curve is 0.2, and the distance between two adjacent iso-contours is 0.2. In Figure 9(d), the values of the top and lower right curves are 0.2 and 2.0, respectively, and the distance between two adjacent iso-contours is 0.2. In Figure 9(e), the values of the left and right curves are 0.6 and 1.6 respectively, and the distance between two adjacent iso-contours is 0.2.

caption.p: Plots of iso-surface and iso-contours of equivalence ratio in the cylinder at various crank angles and fuel amount histories.

sec.p: Simulated in-cylinder pressures were compared to measured data from dynamometer engine tests. The combustion model constants15–17 were calibrated as follows: cm1 = 2.0, cm2 = 0.44, and the results are shown in Figure 10. The RON of this case is 91. In the simulation, two fuel species ic8h18 and c7h16 were used to represent the fuel, as shown in the evaporation history plots of Figure 11. It is seen that very good agreement was obtained between simulated and measured pressures. The flame propagation processes in the cylinder are also shown in Figure 11. In Figure 11, the red surface is the G = 0 iso-surface, which denotes the flame front. In addition, the mass fraction distributions of ic8h18 and c7h16 are shown in the figure. The mass fraction of ic8h18 is shown in the cross-section that bisects the intake valves, and the mass fraction of c7h16 is shown in the cross-section that is normal to the ic8h18 cross-section. From Figure 11, it is seen that the mass fraction of ic8h18 is much higher than c7h16 because the RON is 91. Actually, the mass fractions of ic8h18 and c7h16 dynamically change, and thus the flame speed is affected by the fuel composition. This shows the advantage of using the DMC approach to track the discrete fuel components.

sec.title: PRF 98 engine case
sec.p: In this section, an engine case fueled with a RON of 98 was simulated. Most parameters of the engine in this section are the same as the PRF 91 case. However, two different intake ports were used: port 8 and XO, and the spark timings for port 8 and XO are 719 °CA and 709 °CA, respectively. Simulated in-cylinder pressures and burn rates were compared to the measured data from dynamometer engine tests, and the results are shown in Figure 12. It is seen that good agreement was obtained between the simulated and measured pressures and burn rates.

sec.title: PRF 100 engine case
sec.p: In this section, an engine case fueled with an iso-octane (PRF=100) was simulated. Simulated in-cylinder pressures and heat release rates were compared to the measured data from dynamometer engine tests, and the results are shown in Figure 13. It is seen that good agreement was obtained between the simulated and measured pressures and heat release rates.

list-item.p: With the present integrated KIVA-DMC-G_equation code, the evaporation processes of multi-component automotive fuels were successfully simulated using a DMC evaporation model under various evaporation conditions, including flash-boiling evaporation.
Multi-component single-droplet evaporation differs significantly from that of a single-component fuel in terms of the time histories of their respective evaporation constants and droplet life times.

The present DMC fuel evaporation model for multi-component sprays predicted different distributions of liquid droplets and fuel mass fractions to those from the corresponding single-component fuel. Preferential evaporation of the light-end components of multi-component fuels increases the amount of light-end components upstream of the spray plume. On the contrary, the heavy-end components are found predominantly in the region near the tip of the spray.
The present proposed ‘blending cetane number’ approach allows integration of the DMC fuel evaporation model with the G-equation flame propagation combustion model.

The integrated KIVA-DMC-G_equation code was found to be useful for simulating a GTDI engine. With this code, more realistic characteristics of mass fraction distributions of fuel components and flame speed are captured adequately.
